content.description:
Immediately left of "My first bulge" is a small foot ramp that leads to a small blank section. Balance up this ramp and grab the jugs on top and mantle. Attempt to avoid the holds on the route to the left.

This problem feels half independent and half pretty contrived. You can decide if it was worth it.
This is the left most V0 described in the hand drawn topo, I just gave it an easy name. Step up onto a low foot ledge and climb directly over the bulge on pretty big holds. Pretty fun!
content.location: find the smallish bulge on the left side of the cutfinger boulder, seemingly pretty obvious.

content.description: Sit-start variation to "Ramp Mantle." Sit-start with hands on the mantle ledge and left heel-hook along the ramp. Once you're ontop of the mantle, resist the temptation to take Ramp Mantle to the top. Stay right and enjoy the ride
The far left arete of the Cutfinger boulder. Climb up low angle large holds and rock over the top.
content.location: Left of the more difficult problems on the main face

content.description:
Start with your hands matched on the sloping foot ramp described in "Ramp Mantle", and crank out through terrible holds trending right until finally throwing to the jugs on Cutfinger. Tricky beta, tendons of steel, and a lot of grunting will help you send this problem.

Finish out Cutfinger and celebrate.

Refer to 3:21 in this video:

vimeo.com/138093282
content.protection: pad, a video camera for your ego in-case you do send.
content.location: Traverses a lot of the Cutfinger problems

content.description: Start on the obvious jug (same start as The Grand Traverse) and break out right on the slopers and then up the crimps, finish by throwing/reaching for the left hand diagonal crimp. Donâ€™t stand on top of the start hold unless trying to avoid the hard moves!

Directly below the starting holds of Cutfinger, locate two pretty awful underclings under a bulge. Grab these holds, plant your feet on the obvious footholds, and toss up to the starting jug of Cutfinger. It is kind of a funky half crouch start depending on how tall you are. The hard move felt impossible to me until I finagled the my left foot into the perfect spot.

This problem is a lot of fun, and definitely adds some value to Cutfinger.
content.location: Find Cutfinger, find the garbage underclings, go for it.

content.description: One of the earliest true boulder problems in the US.  First climbed by Dick Emerson sometime around 1956, and originally rated 5.9, the namesake Cut Finger hold was broken off in 1958, rendering the route relatively harmless in that regard.
content.protection: Pad, or not for the historical value.
content.location: Obvious right facing flake on the south face of Cutfinger Rock.

content.description: Plant a foot on the good hold, and step into this problem. Throw a right hand up to the arete, and slap up and left until you can mantle out. To start a left micro crimp is helpful just to keep your balance.
content.location: On the right side of the Cutfinger boulder, locate a grey blank face.

climbs.name: Cut Finger Arete
climbs.fa: John Gill et al ca. late 1950s

content.description:
One of the more challenging problems on Cutfinger, and another impressive effort by the likes of Gill, Chouinard, Kamps, etc. Especially considering their shoes and other gear.

Stand start the slight arete in the middle of the boulder, right hand on a flat gaston, left hand on a small sidepull crimp in a small crack/bulge.  Stab up to another small crimp in a diagonal seam, then up to the top.
